QuestionStem: Animals are classified into at least 30 groups, called phyla. The nine animals shown in this gallery represent nine different phyla. These nine phyla contain most of the animals that exist on Earth today. Explore the photos to discover more about these animals.

images.caption: This barrel sponge belongs to the phylum Porifera. It lives in coral reefs and other shallow ocean waters. Sponges do not have mouths. Instead, they filter food particles from the water.
images.altText: This photograph shows an animal that resembles a hollow barrel. It has a very rough outer surface and a circular opening at the top.

images.caption: The phylum Cnidaria includes sea anemones, corals, and jellyfish, such as the one shown here. Jellyfish bodies are made entirely of soft tissues. They have one body opening where food goes in and out.
images.altText: This photograph shows a jellyfish. Its body structure resembles a mushroom. Its surface appears soft and flexible.

images.caption: This animal, commonly called a flatworm, belongs to the phylum Platyhelminthes. Platyhelminthes have a well-developed muscular system, but do not have specialized systems for circulation or respiration.
images.altText: This photograph shows an aquatic worm. Its body is flattened and it has colorful markings.

images.caption: Members of the phylum Nematoda are commonly called nematodes or roundworms. Nematodes do not have a body system for moving nutrients and oxygen throughout the body. Instead, these molecules move freely in the body cavity.
images.altText: This photograph shows a worm with a body that is coiled, or spiral-shaped.

images.caption: Animals in the phylum Mollusca live on land, in fresh water, and in the ocean. Snails, slugs, squids, octopuses, and nautiluses are mollusks. This bigfin reef squid moves by the force of squirting water.
images.altText: This photograph shows the body structure of a squid. Its body shape is similar to a fish's body, but it has no fins. It has large eyes and tentacles extending from its face.

images.caption: Animals in the phylum Annelida include this earthworm. Earthworms have a body filled with fluid. They move by manipulating the fluid pressure in the cavity to produce force.
images.altText: This photograph shows an earthworm curled in the soil.

images.caption: Most animals of the phylum Arthropoda are insects. Spiders, scorpions, and crabs, like this red rock crab, are also arthropods. All arthropods have an external skeleton, called an exoskeleton.
images.altText: This photograph shows a crab with a shelled body, eight jointed legs, and pincers.

images.caption: All members of the phylum Echinodermata live in salt water. Echinoderms include sea urchins, sand dollars, sea cucumbers, and sea stars. Echinoderms come in many shapes, but many have five parts, like this sea star.
images.altText: This photograph shows a star-shaped aquatic organism.

images.caption: Animals in the phylum Chordata include birds, reptiles, fishes, amphibians, and mammals, such as this okapi. All chordates have a head, tail, and spinal cord, and right and left sides of the body.
images.altText: This photograph shows a four-legged animal with fur and a tail.
